properties.name: Adelia's Closet
properties.description: Posted by Circus 6354 West Gunnison St, Chicago, IL

properties.name: Albany Home #1
properties.description: Posted by Circus 330 Hudson Ave, Albany, NYI was born in Troy, NY, but we moved from there when I was only a few months old. Moving to Albany was almost like coming full circle. My first apartment in Albany was a basement apartment in a row house on a street of late 19th century brick houses and brownstones in a neighborhood called Center Square. It\'s a great neighborhood. In the snow it feels like something out of a Dickens novel. Some of the houses have beautiful ironwork railings. As evening deepens, you can imagine it by gaslight, the occasional horsedrawn carriage clopping slowly up the hill.

properties.name: Albany Home #2
properties.description: Posted by Circus123 Ryckman Ave, Albany, NYWhen my partner decided to move in with me (all the way from Boston), we decided we couldn\'t live together in my little one-bedroom basement apartment. Especially since she was bringing two cats into the arrangement. I\'m not sure how we found this place; I think there might have been an ad for it in the paper. In any case, it turned out that the previous occupants had been on vacation for a month before the move-out date, so I had to move in on the same day that they were moving out. Their words of wisdom for me regarding the apartment? "Good luck." I wanted to ask what they meant by it, but they said the place was fine. I moved in (thanks to the help of a few good friends), and a week or two later I went to Boston, helped my partner load up her stuff, and we came back together. The apartment was okay, but it turns out the landlord was not very responsive. And he had several violations registered with Buildings & Codes (I still remember the police Lieutenant saying, "What are those other two doors up there? What do you mean there are six apartments in this building? He only has four registered..."). We lost a neighbor to carbon monoxide poisoning (she didn\'t die, she moved out), and the neighbor after her managed to blow up the oven (this was after we left). We spent a year in this apartment. I\'m so glad we moved. There is one thing I miss, though: the hallway. Our younger cat was a kitten when we were living there, and she\'d race up the hallway, chirping to herself, skid into the living room, and race back down to the bedroom. It was more entertaining than television. (Duration: July 2003 - July 2004)

properties.name: Albany Home #3
properties.description: Posted by Circus 359D Hackett Blvd, Albany, NYSuch a delightful change after our last apartment! Here\'s a place run by a management company, with 24-hour emergency maintenance. It\'s a two-floor brick townhouse with a basement. The front half of the house gets great light in the morning. One of these days we\'ll have it cleaned up enough that people can stay in the spare room...

properties.name: Andy's Jazz Club
properties.description: Posted by Circus11 E Hubbard St, Chicago, IL, 60611

properties.name: Book House of Stuyvesant Plaza
properties.description: Posted by CircusStuyvesant Plaza, Albany, NYOne of my favorite independent bookstores.

properties.name: Boston Home #2
properties.description: Posted by Circus 35 Fairmount Ave, Somerville, MAI only moved once in the time that I lived in the Boston area--from Brighton to Somerville. The house on Fairmount was a three-level Victorian, forced air heating, no insulation. My room, on the third floor, in the back of the house, was the hottest in the summer and the coldest in the summer. The guy who owned it sold it for a ridiculous sum of money--something like 00,000-700,000. Isn\'t that sick?

properties.name: Boston Public Library - front steps
properties.description: Posted by Circus 700 Boylston St, Boston, MAI proposed to my partner here. Nevermind the fact that we can\'t legally be married in the state in which we currently live. We met in Boston when we were both going through some rough times. For some reason everything seemed to work out with us, though. I think of it as luck. Or maybe fate. In any case, it worked out well enough that I decided to propose on our first anniversary. The proposal went like this: the day before, I emailed her some directions (like, bring Scotch tape to the BPL at such-and-such hour, etc.). I sped back to Boston from Albany, paid off the ring she\'d chosen ages ago (and on which I\'d been making steady payments for months), went the library, and laid out some clues--envelopes containing cut up postcards with more clues written on the back. When everything was set up, I sat back and watched as she went through my little Amelie-inspired treasure hunt kind of thing, and at the end, I met her on the front steps of the BPL with the ring in my pocket and proposed. Oddly enough, it also happened to be Buddha\'s Birthday. There was a celebration for it happening in Copley Square, and it just felt right. We wandered through and watched the festivities, then went off for lunch at a nearby place. It was perfect.

properties.name: Bourgeois Pig
properties.description: Posted by Justsomegirl 735 W. Fullerton, Chicago, ilCozy academic coffeehouse in the De Paul area. Outdoor seating in warm months.

properties.name: Cafe Avanti
properties.description: Posted by Circus 3714 North Southport Ave, Chicago, IL

properties.name: Comicopia
properties.description: Posted by Circus464 Commonwealth Ave Ste 13, Boston, MAThis place fed (and massively increased) my comic book addiction when I lived in Boston. I have many fine memories of browsing the independents and the Vertigo titles, looking for something that might fill the void left by the conclusions of The Sandman and Transmetropolitan. This was the place that introduced me to Finder. Good times.

properties.name: Count Basie Theatre
properties.description: Posted by Circus 99 Monmouth St, Red Bank, NJThe Count Basie Theatre is a historic performance space in Red Bank, NJ. Red Bank itself is a neat little historic town with a very walkable mixed-use downtown. In high school, I\'d often visit Red Bank and just wander around, window shopping and daydreaming. I\'ve only ever seen one show at the Count Basie, but it\'s a wonderful performance space--small but with good acoustics, perfect for seeing the kinds of bands who are more interested in musicianship than special effects. Shows I\'ve seen there: King Crimson (back in the mid- to late 90s, when they had the double trio setup with Pat Mastelotto AND Bill Bruford on the same stage)

properties.name: Dove & Hudson Bookshop
properties.description: Posted by Circus296 Hudson Ave, Albany, NYThis place has become one of my three favorite used bookstores. The other two are (or were) both in the Boston area (one of them closed down a while ago due to the insane rents there). Anyway, the prices at Dove & Hudson are impossible to beat, and the owner is extremely knowledgeable and has amazingly good taste. There isn\'t a single bad book on the shelves. The selection of fiction includes some real literary gems, but the best section is probably the "Eclectic Authors" section, which includes works by people like John McPhee and C.S. Lewis. It\'s the perfect place to be on a rainy Saturday morning.

properties.name: Green Dolphin Street
properties.description: Posted by Circus2200 North Ashland Ave, Chicago, IL

properties.name: Harvard Square
properties.description: Posted by Ketau02138Harvard Square, Cambridge MA

properties.name: Home #4
properties.description: Posted by CircusMainz, GermanySometimes bad things happen in good places. I have good memories of it anyway. Mainz is on the Rhine River, and it\'s probably nothing like I remember it. Here\'s what I remember: going to the market with my mom, and her asking for vegetables by the kilo. The public pool. Mainz-Castel\'s Legoland store, and sidewalk artists creating chalk portraits of the Virgin Mary. My sister tricking me into eating a mushroom on a slice of cheese pizza at the Pizza Barn. The post where we lived is long gone, I think. I know for a fact that the school I attended closed down a year or two after we left (thanks to helpful DoD people for the information). I\'d like to go back some day, even if it means looking at a ghost town. (Age: 5 - 8)

properties.name: Home #5
properties.description: Posted by Circus 5409 64th Ave W, Tacoma, WAWhen my father was transferred to Ft. Lewis, WA, my parents decided that we should live off post. They bought a house in a development called Stonewood. We had just moved from Germany, and the climate was similar, but all the same there was something magical about this place. To this day I still miss the towering pines and the way the light filtered through the perpetual mist. Everything seemed to glow. Every rock hid a treasure. It was the perfect place to be a kid. (Age: 8 - 12)

properties.name: Home #6
properties.description: Posted by Circus ft dix njHolly Crest, Ft Dix, NJ. If I never go back there again, I won\'t mind. From the moment we arrived (and were told to stay at the cockroach-infested Laurel Notch Lodge) to the time we left, this place was hell. But my father had his command, and that was important - 195th Ordinance Bn, cooks and mechanics. (Age: 12 - 15)

properties.name: Home #7
properties.description: Posted by Circus 14 Russel Ave, Ft Monmouth, NJIt was the shortest move we\'d ever do with the military: fifty or so miles from Ft. Dix, NJ to Ft. Monmouth, NJ. My father was transferred to Ft. Monmouth a year before we actually moved; he commuted from Dix to Monmouth every day that year because they didn\'t have quaters ready for us. When we did move, the quarters were much larger (I used to joke that the quarters at Dix were "eighths" because they were so small), and the two posts really couldn\'t be any different. Ft. Dix was a dry, hot hell in the middle of nowhere; Ft. Monmouth was green and set in a pleasant (and affluent) historic area near the Shore. Our quaters on Ft. Monmouth were located across the street from the parade grounds, which were liberally fertilized by Canada geese for much of the year. At the eastern end of the grounds was a square of concrete--a helicopter landing pad. Visiting generals would be flown in by choppers that would land there (I remember seeing a lot of Hueys). I think maybe that\'s why even now, all these years later, it doesn\'t bother me when helicopters fly in close. (Age: 15 - 17)

properties.name: Home #8
properties.description: Posted by Circus 321 port-au-peck ave oceanport njWhen I was a junior in high school, my father retired from the army and took a job in the defense industry. We\'d lived in army quarters for the previous five years or so, but we\'d never live in quarters again. My parents bought a house in Oceanport, NJ, about half a mile from the entrance of Monmouth Park Race Track (it\'s a horse racing track). Nearly eleven years after my parents bought the house, my father died of pancreatic cancer (September 2002). I\'m happy to say that he died in the house, on hospice, and not in a hospital. My mom and I were there when he died. It took my mom three and a half years to make the decision to sell the place. I last saw it at the end of June 2005, her things packed up and almost ready for the movers. Years before, shortly after we moved in, my father and I built a brick walkway in the back yard--and I do mean built; I actually cut bricks for the job. It was July 4th weekend and something like 104F in the shade. Before I left the house for the last time, I took a photo of that walkway.

properties.name: Northeastern University - College of Criminal Justice
properties.description: Posted by CircusHuntington Ave, Boston, MAIt took forever, but I finished a M.S. in Criminal Justice here. When I started the program I\'d been out of school for about three years, having dropped out of another graduate program (at Boston University). At the time, Harry Potter was just gathering steam--I think they\'d just released the third book. I started reading the series around the time that my classes at Northeastern started, and I remember the excitement of the books carrying over, mentally recasting professors as equivalents in Rowling\'s world. It made classwork that much more fun, even for a mid-twenty-something.

properties.name: Origins
properties.description: Posted by CircusPalermo, ItalyMy mother\'s family came from a town not too far from Palermo. We visited once when I was seven and I\'d love to go back again as an adult.

properties.name: Prague
properties.description: Posted by CircusPrague is one of the great European cities I\'ve never visited but plan on seeing someday.

properties.name: Proctor's Theatre
properties.description: Posted by Circus 432 State St, Schenectady, NY I like historic spaces, especially theatres. This particular place is surprising when you visit; it looks much smaller on the outside than it actually is. I believe there\'s only one auditorium (maybe two?), but it\'s a beautiful and interesting space. There\'s also a large concourse inside the building where there are tons of neat little shops. It\'s hard not to imagine what it must have been like in the 1920s and 30s, back when Schenectady was a booming town. Shows I\'ve seen there: Cirque Eloize

properties.description: Posted by Circus  408 South Michigan Avenue, Chicago, IL, 60605Rain Dog Books & Cafe 312-922-1200

properties.name: The Art Institute of Chicago
properties.description: Posted by Paulirving  111 South Michigan Avenue, Chicago, Illinois 60603-6404The Art Institute of Chicago is one of the premier art museums and art schools in the United States, known especially for the extensive collection of Impressionist and American art in its museum. It is located on the western edge of Grant Park, at 111 South Michigan Avenue in Chicago, Illinois.

properties.name: The Egg (Performing Arts Center)
properties.description: Posted by Circus If you\'ve never seen this place, be warned: it\'s pretty odd. It was one of my first landmarks in Albany because of its distinctive UFO-like shape (and I\'m sure this is the case for many transplants to the area). Turns out it\'s quite a nice performance space--two intimate auditoriums and not a single bad seat in the house. I was once told that there were three or four other buildings like this one in the world, and this is the only one left standing, the others having collapsed due to structural failure. I don\'t think this story is true (and the little bit of research I\'ve done on it failed to turn up any evidence in the story\'s favor). Shows I\'ve seen here so far: STREB!, Savion Glover (twice), the Dresden Dolls. Shows I\'m kicking myself for missing: Martin Sexton, the Indigo Girls.

properties.name: The Orpheum
properties.description: Posted by Circus 1 Hamilton Pl, Boston, MAI saw Martin Sexton play here. It was an absolutely mindblowing show--I\'ve never seen a two-person act with such depth and resonance. His live CD, Live Wide Open, has since become one of my absolute favorites. Beautiful venue.

properties.name: Uncommon Grounds
properties.description: Posted by Circus1235 Western Ave, Albany, NYThis is my regular haunt in Albany. It\'s very different from the coffee shops where I usually hang out, but the coffee\'s good and the staff is excellent and occasionally they even play good music. ;) In all seriousness, there are few places in Albany that feel as comfortable and familiar to me as this place. Good food, good coffee, free wifi, and plenty of space make this an almost ideal place to hang out and read or browse the \'net on a rainy day.
